questions.question_text: While doing a technical assessment to determine network vulnerabilities, you used the TCP XMAS scan. What would be the response of all open ports?

choices.B: The port will send a SYN
choices.C: The port will ignore the packets
choices.D: The port will send an RST
choices.A: The port will send an ACK

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Xmas scan is a type of inverse TCP scanning technique with the FIN, URG, and PUSH flags set to send a TCP frame to a remote device. If the target has opened the port, then you will receive no response from the remote system. If the target has closed the port, then you will receive a remote system reply with an RST.
The key part of this questions is what TOOL should you use. thus the answer has to be C since creating an account is not a "tool". if it didnt say tool then it would be creating a user account.
This should be C. download and install netcat.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST way to protect Personally Identifiable Information (PII) from being exploited due to vulnerabilities of varying web applications?

choices.B: Use full disk encryption on all hard drives to protect PII
choices.A: Use cryptographic storage to store all PII
choices.D: Use a security token to log into all Web applications that use PII
choices.C: Use encrypted communications protocols to transmit PII

choices.D: This is a common behavior for a corrupted nmap application
choices.C: The outgoing TCP/IP fingerprinting is blocked by the host firewall

questions.question_text:
Jack was attempting to fingerprint all machines in the network using the following Nmap syntax: invictus@victim_server:~$ nmap -T4 -0 10.10.0.0/24
TCP/IP fingerprinting (for OS scan) xxxxxxx xxxxxx xxxxxxxxx. QUITTING!
Obviously, it is not going through. What is the issue here?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I believe is A, because you have "TCP/IP fingerprinting (for OS scan) xxxxxxx xxxxxx xxxxxxxxx. QUITTING!", is recognizing that a OS scan was started.

Selected Answer: B
the syntax is wrong, they wrote 0 instead of O
B. The nmap syntax is wrong.
